Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Design and Synthesis of Particles for Opto-magnetic Trapping

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1507758
PI: Clark, Robert

Scientists and engineers have available several methods to manipulate particles and their environments at the micron scale. Two such methods, optical trapping and magnetic trapping, offer the advantage that particles can be manipulated using external fields without direct access to the system. These two techniques can be combined to improve particle manipulation, but few particles have the required properties to respond to both optical and magnetic trapping. This project will develop oriented magnetic micro-particles with appropriate arrangements of material properties to give the particles superior properties for combined optical and magnetic manipulation.

This project presents an advanced manufacturing technique for producing a novel type of super-paramagnetic microparticle capable of simultaneous optical and magnetic trapping and manipulation. These particles are produced via the directed self-assembly of magnetic nano-particles within an optically nonlinear fluid media. The optically nonlinear media is then exposed to a shaped ultrafast laser source causing the formation of particles due to multiphoton absorption phase change. The magnetic properties of the new particles will far exceed those of current state of the art particles and will be influential and potentially transformative in biotechnology applications involving molecular spectroscopy and advanced manufacturing of smart structures such as adaptive liquid crystal-based imaging systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main outcome of this project is an advanced manufacturing technique for Oriented Magnetic Micro-Particles (OMMPs), a novel type of super-paramagnetic (SPM) micro-particle capable of simultaneous optical and magnetic manipulation. OMMPs are produced through parallel micromachining and photo-patterning techniques that permit full control of the OMMP size, shape, and composition. The magnetic properties of OMMPs exceed those of current state-of-the-art particles because they feature oriented SPM layers, rather than isotopically distributed SPM materials. OMMPs will be influential and potentially transformative in numerous applications in physics, optics, biotechnology and advanced manufacturing because of their combined opto-magnetic addressability. Combined opto-magnetic trapping (OMT) offers control of particles in six degrees of freedom for precise positioning and manipulation.

The manufacturing methods developed in this study enable scalable production of the opto-magnetic micron-size colloids. These methods can now serve as an enabling technology, allowing for advances in a wide range of fields. The use of OMMPs may be applied in the biological sciences to conduct experiments in tortuous environments with enhanced torque and force capabilities. Experiments involving in vivo cellular stiffness measurements or within cellular scaffolds are just two examples of such research paths. Furthermore, the use of such optomagnetically controllable particles can enable new basic research in light and matter interaction at nano-scales.

Anisotropic colloids with combined dielectric and magnetic properties will be beneficial and potentially transformative to other advanced manufacturing processes. A primary example of this is the use of such colloids in generating adaptable microlens arrays with colloids and liquid crystals, which could lead to potentially transformative breakthroughs for imaging and projection technologies including advanced smart phone and consumer cameras, endoscopic imaging for medical diagnostics, wavefront sensing technologies, and plenoptic cameras which enable 3D photography.

Considering highly experimental nature of this project, it provided an excellent training opportunity for the next generation of scientists and engineers through the involvement of undergraduate and graduate students. This project has provided several undergraduate research experiences and three graduate research experiences to students in chemical engineering and materials sciences.

Students, participated in this project, we'll be able to tackle a variety of applied experimental problems in nano- and micro-manufacturing, interfacial engineering, materials science, electronics and optics by gaining expertise with a broad range of tools and techniques. Both graduates and undergraduates were trained in micromachining, lithography, optics, electromagnetism, instrumentation design, control systems, and colloidal science.


Last Modified: 08/30/2019
Modified by: Robert L Clark
